author: By Hurubie Meko and Wesley Parnell
title: Twist in Dancer’s Killing as Key Detail About Suspect Is Corrected
description: When O’Shae Sibley was killed, initial reports said that his attacker was Muslim, and officials feared that relations between gay people and Muslims in New York could be affected.
content: In the days after O’Shae Sibley, a Black gay man, was killed during an altercation outside a gas station in the Midwood neighborhood of Brooklyn, the picture that emerged suggested an explosive combination of homophobia, religious intolerance and racism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: The Big Business of Dressing Like a Little Girl
description: The fashion designer Sandy Liang has brought her twist on nostalgia to buzzy collaborations with companies including Vans, Target and now Baggu.
content: Sandy Liang has long been attached to bows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen
title: This Is a Reminder That You’re Probably Oversharing on Venmo
description: The mobile wallet service is a cautionary tale of how apps born at least a decade ago may be exposing more information than you would like.
content: There’s an app for snooping on your friends, family and colleagues to find out about their fancy dinners, the people they are dating and the parties they are attending that you weren’t invited to.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: 98 Arrests in Child Abuse Inquiry That Followed Killing of F.B.I. Agents
description: The investigation the two agents were part of grew into a larger inquiry that netted members of an online pedophile ring in the U.S. and Australia.
content: It was among the most traumatic days in the F.B.I.’s history: On Feb. 2, 2021, two agents were killed when a suspect in a child abuse case opened fire on them as they tried to search his Florida apartment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amal El-Mohtar
title: Witches, Robots and Martial Artists, Ready for Battle
description: New books by Juno Dawson, Emma Mieko Candon and Alexander Darwin.
content: Juno Dawson’s “Her Majesty’s Royal Coven” ended on a shocking cliffhanger (which I will spoil at the end of this paragraph), and THE SHADOW CABINET (Penguin Books, 508 pp., paperback, $17) picks up where it left off. The first book introduced Niamh, Helena, Leonie and Elle, modern-day witches with a friendship modeled on the Spice Girls. Largely absent was Ciara, Niamh’s twin sister, who was in a nine-year coma after picking the wrong side of a war. At the end of the book, Ciara wakes, magically swaps bodies with Niamh and kills her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Amos Badertscher, Who Documented a Sexual Underground, Dies at 86
description: He took intimate photographic portraits of hustlers, prostitutes and drag queens on Baltimore’s streets and in gay bars.
content: Amos Badertscher, a self-taught photographer whose stark, powerful and sometimes erotic images of hustlers, prostitutes and drag queens in Baltimore reflected his empathy for people living on the fringes of the city, died on July 24 in Baltimore. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: U.S. Restricts Investment in China
description: Plus, Taylor Swift’s dance moves.
content: President Biden escalated his confrontation with China today by banning American investments in key Chinese tech industries that could enhance Beijing’s military and surveillance capabilities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Special Counsel Obtained Search Warrant for Trump’s Twitter Account
description: The warrant, obtained in January, is the first known example of prosecutors directly searching Donald J. Trump’s communications in the federal inquiry into the events of Jan. 6, 2021.
content: Prosecutors working for Jack Smith, the special counsel who has twice brought indictments against former President Donald J. Trump, obtained a search warrant early this year for Mr. Trump’s long-dormant Twitter account as part of their inquiry into his attempt to overturn the 2020 election, according to court papers unsealed on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays
title: Mayor Adams Says Migrant Influx Will Cost New York City $12 Billion
description: As newcomers continue to arrive in the hundreds each week, the city increased its estimate for how much it will cost to house them and provide other services.
content: For a year now, Mayor Eric Adams has been sounding the alarm about a humanitarian crisis like few New York City has seen before, as tens of thousands of migrants arrive from the southern border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Akerman
title: Why Televising the Trump Trials Is a Bad Idea
description: The arguments in favor of putting the Trump trials on TV are missing key considerations on safety and integrity.
content: As the indictments against former President Donald Trump multiply, TV and print media commentators as well as members of Congress have called for cameras in the courtroom. They claim that broadcasting the trials will increase the public’s understanding of the charges and the evidence against Mr. Trump and that it is the only way there can be full transparency. Even Mr. Trump’s lawyer John Lauro says he wants the American public to see “what kind of prosecution is going on.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $3 Million Homes in Minnesota, North Carolina and Florida
description: An Arts and Crafts house in Minneapolis, a Tudor Revival home in Asheville and a Mediterranean-style retreat in Fort Lauderdale.
content: This house is on a wide, tree-lined street half a block from Lake of the Isles, where a walking trail winds around the water and an outdoor skating rink is a popular gathering spot in the winter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
title: U.S. Nurse and Her Child Released by Kidnappers in Haiti
description: The abduction came as gang violence has begun cresting in Haiti and an international force may be headed to the Caribbean island nation to address the insecurity.
content: Abductors have freed an American nurse working for a humanitarian organization in Haiti and her child, the aid group said Wednesday, after their kidnapping in late July drew international attention to a wave of anarchic violence gripping the capital, Port-au-Prince.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Confusion in Hollywood as Some Productions Are Allowed to Continue
description: The striking actors’ union is granting waivers to some projects not affiliated with the major studios, but questions persist about who qualifies and why.
content: When you’re making an independent film every second counts. Ash Avildsen had six days of filming left on his low-budget biopic “Queen of the Ring” — including a climactic scene involving a majority of his cast — when the actors’ union went on strike on July 14.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: More Plants, More Life, More Pleasure: What Sets the Best Gardens Apart
description: Having an ecologically responsible landscape doesn’t mean you need to get rid of your favorite plants: “It’s about letting things in.”
content: If you want to gauge the effect of a planting design, try letting a 5-year-old loose around it. Then watch his body language.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: After Russian Attack in Ukraine, Broken Glass and Rattled Nerves in Romania
description: A drone assault on a Danube River port sent shock waves — both the physical and the psychological kind — into villages just across the water that are in NATO territory.
content: His thatched-roof shack on the bank of the Danube River just 200 yards from Ukraine has no running water, and getting to it involves waiting for a ferry and a bumpy ride on dirt roads.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Needelman
title: Can Complimenting Strangers Change the World? This Cafe Thinks So.
description: La La Land’s TikTok videos started as an extension of the company’s “kindness mission.” The company has built a following of 6.6 million, showing “how powerful simple acts of kindness are.”
content: More Than Likes is a series about social media personalities who are trying to do positive things for their communities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni and Chris Cameron
title: ‘Ghost Guns’: What They Are and Why There’s a Fight Over Them
description: A rule regulating the firearm kits was a centerpiece of President Biden’s gun control initiative. The Supreme Court has temporarily revived it, but it has been troubled by significant challenges.
content: The Supreme Court has revived, at least for now, the Biden administration’s regulation of “ghost guns,” drawing a spotlight to the kits that can be assembled into homemade firearms and the new front in the fight over gun control that they have opened up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Rodriguez, Singer Whose Career Was Resurrected, Dies at 81
description: Two albums in the early 1970s went largely unnoticed in the United States, but not overseas. Then came the 2012 documentary “Searching for Sugar Man.”
content: Rodriguez, a Detroit musician whose songs, full of protest and stark imagery from the urban streets, failed to find an American audience in the early 1970s but resonated in Australia and especially South Africa, leading to a late-career resurgence captured in the Oscar-winning documentary “Searching for Sugar Man” in 2012, died on Tuesday. He was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Distinctive Flair
description: Caryn Robbins and Matthew Stock make their collaboration debut.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: Dozens of Migrants Die After Boat Sinks in Strait of Sicily
description: Survivors said that 41 people, shunted by traffickers onto a small makeshift iron vessel, had drowned after it capsized en route from Tunisia to Italy.
content: Dozens of migrants died after their boat capsized in the Strait of Sicily, with just a handful rescued, survivors reported on Wednesday, as yet another perilous attempt to cross the Mediterranean in a rickety, unsuitable vessel ended in disaster.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: China’s Economy Faces Yet Another Threat: Falling Prices
description: A deepening slowdown in the world’s second-biggest economy has now raised fears of deflation, which could be crippling for heavily indebted China.
content: The United States has spent much of the past 18 months struggling to control inflation. China is experiencing the opposite problem: People and businesses are not spending, pushing the economy to the verge of a pernicious condition called deflation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt and Ian Prasad Philbrick
title: A Winning Streak
description: Ballot initiatives appear to be one of the few ways for advocates to expand abortion access in conservative states.
content: Once again, abortion access has won a victory at the polls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zeynep Tufekci
title: Why Haven’t We Made It Safer to Breathe in Classrooms?
description: Too few schools have used Covid relief funds to improve air quality properly.
content: Two years ago, we got a chance to assure parents and teachers, in any future epidemic, that the air in classrooms was safer, making it easier for children to attend school in person and avoid learning loss and isolation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: In ‘Operation Mincemeat,’ the Theater of War Is a Comedy
description: How a theater collective transformed the too-weird-to-be-true story of a World War II counterintelligence scheme into a West End musical with heart.
content: The inflatable tanks had to go.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Union Square Melee Shows an Influencer’s Power Unleashed in Real Life
description: Kai Cenat is a perfect example of the new type of celebrity. How did he summon a crowd of thousands to Manhattan last week?
content: Kai Cenat was live online last week when he began planning himself a homecoming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien and Shane Goldmacher
title: DeSantis, With a Subtle Maneuver, Hides His Small-Dollar Donations
description: The campaign of the Florida governor, who is known to be reliant on rich donors, worked with a Republican fund-raising powerhouse to prevent the disclosure of information on small contributors.
content: When WinRed, the company that processes nearly all online Republican campaign contributions, recently released its enormous trove of donor data for the first half of the year, donations were conspicuously absent for one presidential candidate: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Valeriya Safronova
title: Explosion Rocks Russian Military Optics Plant Near Moscow
description: Russian officials said one person was killed and dozens were injured in the blast. The warehouse is on the grounds of a plant that has produced night vision devices and binoculars, according to local news media.
content: A powerful explosion ripped through a warehouse on the grounds of a factory that has made optical gear for the Russian military outside Moscow on Wednesday, officials said, killing one person, injuring dozens and sending up an enormous plume of smoke visible for miles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cindy Shmerler
title: Alice K. Ladas, Author of Landmark Book on Female Sexuality, Dies at 102
description: Working with collaborators, she wrote “The G Spot,” which became a cultural sensation and sold more than a million copies.
content: Alice Kahn Ladas, a psychologist and psychotherapist whose best-selling 1982 book, “The G Spot: And Other Recent Discoveries About Human Sexuality,” created a tipping point for female sensual autonomy by introducing ways for women to experience greater sexual pleasure, died on July 29 at her home in Santa Fe, N.M. She was 102.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Hickley
title: How 4 Countries Are Preparing to Bring Stolen Treasures Home
description: While attention is focused on western museums and governments giving back looted items, heritage workers in the global south are laying the groundwork for new claims.
content: The discussion about returning wrongfully acquired heritage to countries in the global south has, until now, largely focused on the steps taken by Western museums and governments. But away from the spotlight, in countries like Cameroon and Indonesia, heritage workers, government officials and activists are laying the groundwork to reclaim long lost treasures, a process most expect will take decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: Biden to Restrict Investments in China, Citing National Security Threats
description: The measure to clamp down on investments in certain industries deemed to pose security risks, set to be issued Wednesday, appears likely to open a new front in the U.S.-China economic conflict.
content: The Biden administration plans on Wednesday to issue new restrictions on American investments in certain advanced industries in China, according to people familiar with the deliberations, a move that supporters have described as necessary to protect national security but that will undoubtedly rankle Beijing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker and David E. Sanger
title: Biden Orders Ban on New Investments in China’s Sensitive High-Tech Industries
description: The new limits, aimed at preventing American help to Beijing as it modernizes its military, escalate a conflict between the world’s two largest economies.
content: President Biden escalated his confrontation with China on Wednesday by signing an executive order banning new American investment in key technology industries that could be used to enhance Beijing’s military capabilities, the latest in a series of moves putting more distance between the world’s two largest economies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilary Achauer
title: For a Better Workout, Think Like a Kid
description: If you want to move more, look to your childhood and let things get silly.
content: Growing up, Kyle Luigs was a shy kid who loved sports. He finished his sophomore year pitching for the University of North Georgia in 2018 and needed somewhere to play during the summer, so he decided to try out for a team called the Savannah Bananas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: The Concorde Is Taking a Slow Boat to Brooklyn
description: The once-glamorous supersonic jet needs a paint job after spending the last 15 years at the Intrepid museum.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Today we’ll find out about a short ride by a once-fast machine. We’ll also get details on a shark bite incident off Rockaway Beach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Jon Batiste Has Got the Whole Wide Music World in His Hands
description: The pianist is following his Grammy win with “World Music Radio,” a concept album that challenges genre borders and carries a message of open-armed inclusivity.
content: Nothing is simple when it comes to Jon Batiste, the pianist, television personality, New Orleans musical scion and jazz-R&B-classical savant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: How the Pac-12 Implosion Could Change West Coast Athletics
description: A conversation with Billy Witz, who covers college sports for The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana G. Smith
title: Don’t Get Your Next Covid Booster Quite Yet
description: A new formulation is coming this fall, and there are two main reasons to wait for it.
content: An uptick in Covid-19 cases and the fast-approaching new school year have many people wondering when they should get their next booster. The short answer, according to experts: not quite yet — you’ll be a lot better off if you wait another month or two.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Enjoli Liston, Valeriya Safronova and Paul Sonne
title: Russia Destroys Drones Near Moscow, as Attacks Far From the Front Line Intensify
description: It was the 12th time in the past three weeks that Russian officials had reported intercepting such aerial attacks in the heart of the capital.
content: Russia shot down two drones near Moscow overnight, officials said on Wednesday, the 12th time in the past three weeks they have reported intercepting such aerial assaults in the heart of the capital. The attacks suggest that the effort to push Russia’s war deep into its own territory was picking up pace amid Ukraine’s marathon counteroffensive to take back occupied territory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Barbara Kingsolver
title: Read Your Way Through Appalachia
description: Barbara Kingsolver, whose Pulitzer-winning “Demon Copperhead” offered a variegated portrait of the region, guides readers through a literary landscape “as bracing and complex as a tumbling mountain creek.”
content: Appalachia is a region and a mind-set. Our devotion to our place belies the fact that we’re hard to pin down on a map: a swath of highlands crossing parts of Georgia, Tennessee, North Carolina, Virginia and the coal country of Kentucky and West Virginia, plus a smidgen of Pennsylvania and points north. State lines make little sense here; we have more in common with other mountain communities than with the far ends of our states and their capitals. Appalachia has few large cities, our economies are land-based and, unless you live here, we’re probably not what you think.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: On the Hottest Days, Make This Cooling Cucumber Dinner
description: Crushed until craggy and tossed with shrimp, cucumbers soak up a sesame and avocado sauce in this easy, invigorating dish from Melissa Clark.
content: The most sweltering part of summer is the time to reach for the coolest of cool produce — the cucumber, of course.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Justin H. Min, Travel Writer? The Path Not Taken for a Rising Star
description: Success came relatively easy — until he tried acting. For a moment, journalism seemed more viable. But now he’s the lead in “Shortcomings.”
content: Five years after Justin H. Min began pursuing acting by Googling “how to pursue acting,” he thought he was getting the hang of it. He had made a viral commercial, and he was in contention for three major roles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsia Rose Marcius and Kate Christobek
title: De Blasio’s Security Chief Admits Hindering Corruption Investigation
description: Howard Redmond pleaded guilty to deleting messages to keep them from investigators, who were looking into whether the former mayor used his police detail for personal and political tasks.
content: The one-time head of security for former mayor Bill de Blasio pleaded guilty in Manhattan on Wednesday to deleting text messages and refusing to give investigators his cellphone during a probe into Mr. de Blasio’s misuse of city funds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anushka Patil
title: A Russian missile hits a bedroom community in the city of Zaporizhzhia, killing 2.
description: Officials said seven people were injured, a church building and several local shops were destroyed, and the windows were blown out of several high-rise buildings.
content: At least two people were killed and seven others injured after a Russian missile struck a residential area of the city of Zaporizhzhia in southeastern Ukraine, Ukrainian officials said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Hoberman
title: ‘Winter Kills’: All of the Plots Thicken
description: Part black comedy, part paranoid thriller, the 1979 movie returns after four decades in a new 35 mm print at Film Forum.
content: A madcap riff on the assassination of President John F. Kennedy, “Winter Kills,” adapted by the director William Richert from Richard Condon’s 1974 best seller, is part black comedy, part paranoid thriller and — an evocation of cosmic conspiracy that boasts its own conspiratorial back story — part carnival hall of mirrors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman, Charlie Savage and Luke Broadwater
title: Previously Secret Memo Laid Out Strategy for Trump to Overturn Biden’s Win
description: The House Jan. 6 committee’s investigation did not uncover the memo, whose existence first came to light in last week’s indictment.
content: A lawyer allied with President Donald J. Trump first laid out a plot to use false slates of electors to subvert the 2020 election in a previously unknown internal campaign memo that prosecutors are portraying as a crucial link in how the Trump team’s efforts evolved into a criminal conspiracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Taylor Kitsch Is No Longer the Next Big Thing. He’s OK With That.
description: After “Friday Night Lights” and several box-office disappointments, he has hit his stride as a character actor. “Painkiller” on Netflix is his most personal project yet.
content: There are easier ways.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Reinvesting in the Business of ‘a Special Player’
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, August 9, 2023.
content: “It’s like watching Michael Jordan, Wayne Gretzky and Tiger Woods play baseball, all in one.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassandra Vinograd
title: Poland says it will send another 2,000 troops to reinforce its border with Belarus.
description: The deployment comes as concerns are mounting in Poland, a NATO member, over the presence of mercenaries from Russia’s Wagner private military company in neighboring Belarus.
content: Poland will send an additional 2,000 troops to reinforce its border with Belarus, a deputy interior minister told Poland’s state news agency on Wednesday, amid heightened tensions in the area related to Russia’s war in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica Berry
title: My Dates Need to Realize I’m Tired of Trying to Be Chill
description: If being alive right now sometimes feels like standing on a cliff, I want to be with someone who’s not afraid to peer at the frothing tides.
content: The day that wildfire smoke triggered the fire alarms in our Portland, Ore., apartment, I looked at my then-boyfriend and decided I could marry him. He was packing a go bag in case a fire reached our house and we would have to evacuate. With global warming and drought exacerbating wildfires, more than one out of 10 Oregonians had already been displaced or was at risk of having to evacuate from burns around the state. My partner was preparing for the worst. This made me feel safe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller
title: Maui Town Is Devastated by Deadliest Wildfire to Strike Hawaii
description: At least six people were killed in an inferno that tore through Lahaina, leveling entire neighborhoods.
content: Follow live updates on the deadly wildfires in Maui, Hawaii.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Mashberg
title: Virginia Museum Will Return ‘Wounded Indian’ Statue to Boston
description: After a decades-long ownership dispute, the Chrysler Museum in Norfolk, Va., will give the 19th-century work back to a Boston organization founded by Paul Revere.
content: A poignant life-size statue of a wounded American Indian, long the subject of a tug of war between a Virginia museum named for Walter P. Chrysler and a Boston organization founded by Paul Revere, will be sent back to Boston in the wake of an investigation by the F.B.I., the Boston group said Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Farber
title: Robbie Robertson, 80, Dies; Canadian Songwriter Captured American Spirit
description: As the chief songwriter and guitarist for the Band, he offered a rustic vision of his adopted country that helped inspire the genre that came to be known as Americana.
content: Robbie Robertson, the chief composer and lead guitarist for the Band, whose work offered a rustic vision of America that seemed at once mythic and authentic, in the process helping to inspire the genre that came to be known as Americana, died on Wednesday in Los Angeles. He was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti and Trip Gabriel
title: Trump Tells Supporters His Criminal Indictments Are About ‘You’
description: The former president, who has made his 2024 campaign principally about his own personal grievances, is attempting to convince supporters to see themselves in him.
content: As lawyers for Donald J. Trump float various legal arguments to defend him in court against an onslaught of criminal charges, the former president has settled on a political defense: “I’m being indicted for you.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: The Absurd Republican Argument for Rolling Back Child Labor Laws
description: Parents’ rights? Come on.
content: Last week, a law went into effect in Arkansas that allows 14- and 15-year-olds to work without a permit signed by their parents. Titled the “Youth Hiring Act of 2023,” it states that the purpose of removing the permit requirement is to “restore decision-making to parents concerning their children” and “streamline the hiring process for children under 16 years of age.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Breihan
title: Too Short’s Long (and Very Raunchy) Life in Rap
description: The West Coast rapper is an unsung pioneer of some of the genre’s most central elements.
content: When Too Short walks onstage, before he says anything else, he asks: “What’s my favorite word?” And audiences of thousands shout: “Biiiiiitch!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yiwen Lu
title: San Francisco Balks at Expanding Driverless Car Services on City’s Roads
description: Local officials are worried that state regulators are too eager about a plan by the companies Cruise and Waymo to offer round-the-clock driverless taxi services.
content: Over the past year or so, a jarring sight has become common in San Francisco: driverless cars buzzing around the city’s streets with no one at the wheel and an expensive array of electronic sensors guiding the way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum
title: Imran Khan Appeals Prison Sentence, Kicking Off High-Stakes Legal Battle
description: The former prime minister of Pakistan was jailed after being found guilty in a corruption case. The legal fight will determine his political future ahead of elections later this year.
content: The legal team for the former prime minister of Pakistan, Imran Khan, appealed his three-year prison sentence on Wednesday, kicking off a high-stakes and hotly contested legal fight that will determine Mr. Khan’s future and the country’s political climate as it heads into general elections later this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: 4 Takeaways From Ohio’s Vote on Abortion and Democratic Power
description: Abortion rights continue to drive turnout, and Republicans are struggling to figure out a response.
content: Ohio voters rejected a ballot measure on Tuesday that would have required a 60 percent supermajority to amend the State Constitution, a proposal designed by Republicans to prevent voters from preserving abortion rights through a constitutional amendment in November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Mark Morris Premieres a Dance More Major Than ‘Minor’
description: In his Joyce Theater debut, Morris unveiled a cheekily titled premiere and “Castor and Pollux,” a lost treasure from his early days.
content: A less confident, more mild-mannered choreographer might not have named his latest work “A minor Dance.” But Mark Morris, saucy and never shy to crack a joke, has done just that with his world premiere set to Bach’s Partita No. 3 in A minor. For this choreographer, music means everything; his title is a wink, not to the work’s worth, but to its key signature.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei and Alfonso Duran
title: An Overrun Miami Suburb Will Snip Its Peacocks (and Not in the Feathers)
description: The birds are breeding and running amok in Pinecrest, Fla. The village will test a novel solution to rein them in: peacock vasectomies.
content: The prevailing theory about why the peacocks flocked to suburban Pinecrest is that, like many a Floridian, they went hunting for better real estate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Ohio Vote Shows Abortion’s Potency to Reshape Elections
description: The Dobbs ruling has turned a coalition of liberal, swing and moderate Republican voters into a political force. Even in August in Ohio.
content: Gov. Mike DeWine of Ohio, a Republican, argued that Tuesday’s vote over how to amend the State Constitution was about protecting the state from a flood of special interest money. Secretary of State Frank LaRose, another Republican, urged voters to protect the “very foundational rules” of their constitution.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Popcast (Deluxe): Lizzo, Travis Scott and the Limits of Persona
description: What can pop stars get away with? Plus: the deaths of Sinead O’Connor and Angus Cloud.
content: This week’s episode of Popcast (Deluxe), the weekly culture roundup show on YouTube hosted by Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli, includes segments on:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: Henry Ruggs Sentenced to at Least 3 Years for Crash That Killed Woman
description: Ruggs, who was released by the Las Vegas Raiders after the crash, had pleaded guilty to reduced charges after his legal team raised questions about how the police gathered a blood sample.
content: A judge on Wednesday sentenced Henry Ruggs III, a former wide receiver for the Raiders, to at least three years in prison for his role in a crash that killed a woman in Las Vegas in 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: Ohio Voters Reject Constitutional Change Intended to Thwart Abortion Amendment
description: The contest was seen as a test of efforts by Republicans nationwide to curb voters’ use of ballot initiatives.
content: Ohio voters rejected a bid on Tuesday to make it harder to amend the State Constitution, according to The Associated Press, a significant victory for abortion-rights supporters trying to stop the Republican-controlled State Legislature from severely restricting the procedure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Santul Nerkar
title: WeWork Has Sent a Distress Signal. Here’s What to Know.
description: The co-working company has declared that its ability to endure as a business is in doubt. A failure could have widespread effects.
content: WeWork, which promised to revolutionize the way people work alongside one another, announced in a financial filing on Tuesday that it had “substantial doubt” it would stay in business. That declaration raises questions about not only the company’s viability but also the future of commercial real estate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bharat Sikka and Raphael Hirsch
title: Fall’s Sinuous New Silhouettes
description: From ruched silk to crisp box pleats, expertly draped dresses and separates make a refined statement this season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: First Scorched, Then Soaked: Weather Whiplash Confounds Farmers
description: As the war in Ukraine disrupts the global grain market, a volatile climate leaves Kansas on track to harvest its smallest wheat crop in decades.
content: This single field, just 160 acres of Kansas dirt, tells the story of a torturous wheat season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei and Frances Robles
title: DeSantis Suspends Second Elected Prosecutor in Florida
description: The Republican governor accused Monique H. Worrell, the state attorney in Orlando and a Democrat, of leniency toward violent criminals, a charge her office has denied.
content: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida suspended the top state prosecutor in Orlando on Wednesday, accusing her of incompetence and neglect of duty for what he characterized as lenience against violent criminals. The move was the governor’s latest aggressive use of executive power against local officials of the opposing political party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: Feinstein Briefly Hospitalized After a Fall at Home in San Francisco
description: Dianne Feinstein, 90, has struggled to navigate the Senate this year after suffering a severe case of shingles in February.
content: Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California, was hospitalized on Tuesday afternoon after a fall at her home in San Francisco and returned to her residence after an examination showed no serious injuries, her spokesman said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: Travel Insurance: What It Covers and When to Buy It
description: The range of benefits and prices for different policies can be complicated. Here’s what you need to know before you buy.
content: In the wake of Covid, travel insurance sales have spiked with the rebound in travel as people seek to protect their investments against flight delays and cancellations, extreme weather events and the persistence of the virus. But travel insurance is complicated with a range of benefits, inclusions and prices. Here’s what you need to know before you buy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Everyone Loves a Lemon Bar
description: Genevieve Ko’s new recipe adds lemon zest to a snappy shortbread crust for even more lemony brightness and flavor.
content: Lemon bars are a Clark family favorite. My mother made them for every bake sale, holiday party and potluck, following the recipe for Lucy’s lemon squares from the “Peanuts” cookbook. Once, she baked a batch for a school function and put them in the back of the kitchen counter for safekeeping. Later, when she saw that half of them had vanished, she started to scold my sister and me until, in a scene fit for a “Peanuts” strip, the dog strolled by with a snout thickly dusted with powdered sugar. Everyone loves a lemon bar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: 3 Deaths, and a Host of Questions, After a Family Lunch in Australia
description: The three guests, and a fourth who fell ill, had symptoms consistent with mushroom poisoning, the police say. The woman who served the meal has been questioned by the police.
content: In the quiet Australian town of Leongatha, a woman hosted her in-laws and another couple for lunch at her home, nestled amid the gum trees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced and Ephrat Livni
title: Lessons From a Law Firm’s Decision to Leave China
description: Dentons’ decision to quit the country and new investment limits by the Biden administration underscore the growing challenges facing Western companies there.
content: The Biden administration is expected to announce new restrictions today on investing in China, its latest effort to prevent Beijing from accessing advanced technologies that could be used by its military.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: soiree
description: This word has appeared in 24 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word soiree has appeared in 24 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on July 24 in “How Do You Party — Barbie Style?” by Alyson Krueger:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: How to Command a Stage Without Great Dance Moves (Taylor’s Version)
description: The choreography on Taylor Swift’s Eras Tour doesn’t ask her to do too much, but she knows how to use her simple moves to her advantage.
content: Since it’s an understatement to call Taylor Swift’s Eras Tour the dominant pop concert of the year, it isn’t surprising that snippets of the show, captured by fans on their phones, have been flooding social media sites for months. Watch a few of these clips, and it might strike you that the dance moves, in contrast to the designer costumes and visual effects, are rather simple and unoriginal, the sort of thing anyone might be able to pull off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: Does Information Affect Our Beliefs?
description: New studies on social media’s influence tell a complicated story.
content: It was the social-science equivalent of Barbenheimer weekend: four blockbuster academic papers, published in two of the world’s leading journals on the same day. Written by elite researchers from universities across the United States, the papers in Nature and Science each examined different aspects of one of the most compelling public-policy issues of our time: how social media is shaping our knowledge, beliefs and behaviors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier and Ismail Alfa
title: No More Coups in West Africa, Nigeria’s Leader Vowed. Niger Called His Bluff.
description: A coup in Niger could shape the future of a West African regional bloc and the presidency of Bola Ahmed Tinubu, the newly elected leader of Nigeria.
content: When President Bola Ahmed Tinubu of Nigeria took the helm of the West African regional bloc of countries last month, he thundered before a roomful of his presidential peers that he would show no tolerance for military coups in an area that had faced five in less than three years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Siegel Bernard
title: Discharging Student Debt in Bankruptcy Is Supposed to Be Easier Than Before
description: Last year, the Biden administration provided a new path to make it easier to discharge student loans in bankruptcy. The results appear promising, but success has been limited.
content: Alista Lineburg is not a lawyer, but she assumed the role when she couldn’t find one to help her discharge $146,000 of federal student debt in bankruptcy. The process requires a separate lawsuit against the government, something that many lawyers refuse to take on given the time, expense and difficulty of winning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Goldman and Jesus Jiménez
title: Utah Man Accused of Threatening Biden Is Killed by F.B.I. Agent
description: The man, who was shot while agents were trying to serve arrest and search warrants at a home, was also charged with threatening other elected officials.
content: An F.B.I. agent on Wednesday fatally shot a man in Provo, Utah, who officials said was armed and had threatened to assassinate President Biden just hours before the president was scheduled to speak in nearby Salt Lake City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsea Leu
title: Horror Stories That’ll Leave You Haunted and Bewitched
description: New books by Rebecca Turkewitz, Tobi Ogundiran and Paul Tremblay captivate with fresh terrors.
content: What becomes eerily palpable in Rebecca Turkewitz’s collection HERE IN THE NIGHT: Stories (Black Lawrence Press, 171 pp., paperback, $21.95) aren’t the specters or vengeful spirits, but the stories people tell about them. A teenage girl makes up a ghost tale with her crush in an attic, and “feels the story taking shape around them.” A receptionist at a New Hampshire hotel fakes evidence that the building is haunted by a local drowned woman, and then ends up seeing her everywhere: “in the faces of the college girls who come for a summer weekend, their hair heavy with saltwater, their eyes trained on the white-capped waves.” One character discovers that she’s the subject of a campus ghost story at her alma mater, a yarn that echoes into an uncanny reality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elie Levine
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Kuo
title: Sorkin’s ‘Mockingbird’ Adaptation Can Be Staged Anywhere, Judge Says
description: A federal judge ruled that a competing theater company no longer has exclusive rights to produce “To Kill a Mockingbird” in community and school theaters.
content: For several years, two theater companies have waged a legal war over which adaptation of “To Kill a Mockingbird,” Harper Lee’s classic coming-of-age novel about Southern racism and injustice in the 1930s, could be staged in smaller theaters across the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: The Montgomery Brawl Was, for Some, a Clarifying Moment
description: It had a sense of historical correction.
content: The Alabama Sweet Tea Party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi
title: WM, 51, Separated, Looks to Rekindle Old Bond — With Voters
description: Justin Trudeau has portrayed himself as a modern husband, father and political figure in his rise to prime minister. How does he redefine himself after the breakup of his 18-year marriage?
content: In 2005, Justin Trudeau, the son of a legendary Canadian prime minister, and Sophie Grégoire, a well-known television journalist, married inside a stone church in Montreal’s wealthy, French-speaking enclave of Outremont.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Aug. 9, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Aug. 9, 2023.
content: An article on Saturday about the revived popu­larity of cruises misstated a measurement of the Icon of the Seas. Its gross tonnage will be about 250,000; it will not displace about 250,000 tons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Can Frozen Peas, Long Taken for Granted, Find New Appeal in the U.K.?
description: Britain’s vegetable producers are hoping this is a moment for the humble frozen pea, a cost-effective staple at a time of rising food prices.
content: As he guided his giant harvester through a field in eastern England, James Williams still had another nine hours to go before finishing his 12-hour shift. Even then, other workers would continue through the night gathering a once ubiquitous vegetable that growers believe could be about to have a new moment in British life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquin
title: Texas Woman Convicted in Toddler’s 2003 Death Is Exonerated
description: Rosa Jimenez spent 18 years of a 99-year sentence behind bars after a toddler she was babysitting choked to death on paper towels. This week, a judge threw out murder charges after prosecutors called into question testimony against her.
content: Rosa Jimenez, a Texas babysitter who had been sentenced to 99 years in prison after being convicted of murder in the 2003 death of a toddler, was exonerated on Monday after years of appeals in which she maintained her innocence and testimony against her was called into question.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: Even 4,000 Steps a Day Can Have Big Health Benefits
description: But the more you walk, the better off you’ll be.
content: Exercise scientists long ago debunked the notion that you need to hit 10,000 steps each day to stay healthy and live longer. Even a little movement is good, they argue, though more is better. Now, a new study underscores that people can reap significant benefits from a comparatively small number of daily steps.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: The Messy Relationship Between Romance Novels and Ice Hockey
description: Hockey romance is a thriving literary subgenre, but some of its fans on TikTok are creating content that blurs the line between fictional players and real-life ones, dividing the community.
content: The niche world of hockey romance novels is getting mainstream attention after the wife of an N.H.L. player criticized book fans who she said had made comments and videos on social media about her husband that were “predatory and exploiting.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: Why Did My Dermatologist Ask Me for a Tip?
description: A reader is perturbed to have been presented with a tip screen while groggily paying for a cosmetic procedure performed by a doctor.
content: I spent a few thousand dollars on cosmetic medical treatments — Botox and fillers — at a spa. The injections were performed by the dermatologist who owns the facility. I am frightened of needles and was nervous about the procedure. Afterward, I was a little out of it — maybe because of my nervousness or the numbing agent. I presented my credit card and was surprised to see a screen asking me to select a tip amount between 15 and 30 percent. I understand why they have this: Some people come to the spa for facials and other treatments performed by aestheticians. So, I selected a 20 percent tip and left. Later, when I felt back to normal, I realized that my tip was several hundred dollars. I have never been asked to tip a doctor before. Should I have been?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ted Loos
title: The Barnes Foundation Loosens Its Straitjacket
description: A judge allowed the Philadelphia institution to lend paintings from the storied collection of Dr. Albert C. Barnes. It will look and behave a lot more like a global museum.
content: If a visitor goes to the Barnes Foundation, and a favorite Cézanne, Matisse or Renoir is missing because it is on loan to the Louvre, is the Barnes still the Barnes?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland and Rachel Bujalski
title: California Battles Fentanyl With a New Tactic: Treating Addiction in Prison
description: In response to soaring overdose deaths in state prisons, California started a sprawling addiction program. But keeping people on medication during and after a sentence can be difficult.
content: In blistering 100-degree heat one recent afternoon at Valley State Prison in California’s Central Valley, inmates crowded around small windows in a prison yard to pick up their daily doses of buprenorphine, an opioid addiction medication.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Thursday Briefing: U.S. restricts China investment
description: Also, bringing stolen treasures home.
content: President Biden escalated his confrontation with China today by banning American investments in key Chinese tech industries that could enhance Beijing’s military and surveillance capabilities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Rikers Watchdog Sues New York City Over Lack of Transparency
description: Members want their access to video from Rikers restored, filing their case the day before a critical hearing that could put the city’s jails on the path to a takeover by a federal court.
content: A New York City agency responsible for protecting the rights of incarcerated people took steps to reassert its authority on Wednesday, suing the Department of Correction and the city over a lack of transparency as the majority of its members called for an outside authority to take control of the jails.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliette Guéron-Gabrielle and Claire Moses
title: Vacation Home Blaze in France Kills 11
description: The victims were on an organized trip for people with mental disabilities in Wintzenheim, near the borders of Germany and Switzerland.
content: A blaze ripped through a vacation rental where 28 travelers were staying in a small idyllic commune in northeastern France on Wednesday morning, killing 11 people, French officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debasish Roy Chowdhury
title: India Is on the Brink
description: Narendra Modi’s intolerant brand of Hindu supremacy threatens to turn India into a conflict zone.
content: Indian social media is a brutal place, a window on the everyday hatred and violence that has come to colonize the country in the nine years since Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s government came to power. But the images from the northeastern state of Manipur that began circulating in July were shocking even by those low standards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Spencer
title: The ‘High School Musical’ Series Is Over. Tim Federle Takes a Bow.
description: After four seasons and the making of a superstar, the Disney+ series comes to an end. Its creator and showrunner unpacked the series and its finale.
content: This interview includes spoilers for the fourth season of “High School Musical: The Musical: The Series.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Was That an Earthquake in Rome? No, It Was a Travis Scott Concert.
description: The rap star’s show in Rome at the Circus Maximus, an archaeological site by day and concert venue by night, has raised concerns about the risks posed by crowds.
content: When Travis Scott asked Rome to make some noise at the Circus Maximus on Monday, Rome cheerfully complied.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Will ‘Future You’ Thank ‘Today You’ for Getting Married?
description: Marriage has clear benefits, but whether they’re worthwhile is hard to know before taking the leap.
content: My son is getting married this weekend, so I’m full of happy thoughts about marriage. But I want to get to those happy thoughts by way of talking about vampires.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung and Ceylan Yeginsu
title: Planning to Visit Hawaii? Here’s What You Need to Know About the Wildfires.
description: Devastating fires on Maui and the Big Island have destroyed businesses and homes, and caused at least six deaths. They are also upending tourism, leaving travelers wondering what to do.
content: Large wildfires burning across the islands of Maui and Hawaii, fueled by intense winds, turned scenic beach destinations into smoky, catastrophic scenes on Wednesday. The fast-moving flames have scorched hundreds of acres, destroyed homes and businesses, and prompted a series of evacuation orders, road closures, and power and cellphone service outages. At least six people have died.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner and Alejandro Cegarra
title: A Baseball Trip to Mexico City. But First, a Pilgrimage.
description: When in the capital for road games, many Mexican League players join the throngs paying their respects at the Basílica de Santa María de Guadalupe.
content: The moment Isidro Piña hopped out of the taxi, he made a beeline for the woman selling candles on the sidewalk. He asked how much they cost — 25 Mexican pesos each, or $1.50 — and whipped out his wallet. He wanted three: one for himself and one for each of the friends who had accompanied him to the Basílica de Santa María de Guadalupe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eilene Zimmerman
title: For Younger Workers, Job Hopping Has Lost Its Stigma. Should It?
description: Repeatedly switching jobs has long been a red flag for employers. That’s changing as Gen Z and younger Millennials embrace the upsides, but downsides persist.
content: Pranav Ravikumar has held three jobs since college, and he’s only 24. One month after graduating in December 2020, he cycled through two rotations of a management training program at the pharmaceutical company Abbott. Mr. Ravikumar became an e-commerce analyst, but he wanted the kind of faster-paced work found at consulting firms and start-ups. The job at Abbott also required him to move to Columbus, Ohio, far from family and friends in Washington, D.C.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Why Barbie and Ken Need Each Other
description: For women maybe first, and for men too, eventually, less wedlock means more woe.
content: Between the middle of the 1970s and the late 2010s, in their responses to the General Social Survey, American women reported themselves to be steadily unhappier. The trend was not drastic, but it was consistent: Women were less happy in the 1980s than they were in the 1970s, less happy in the Obama era than the Clinton era, and still less happy under Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Wallace-Wells
title: Why Is America Such a Deadly Place?
description: A study found millions of Americans would be alive if our mortality rates matched our economic peers’.
content: Death is excessive in America, and the more you look the more distressing the picture seems.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eviana Hartman, Dean Kaufman and Colin King
title: Two Vintage Clothing Dealers’ Greatest Find: Their House
description: The pair behind the boutique Desert Vintage have made a home in an 1860s adobe-brick bungalow in Tucson, Ariz.
content: THOUGH SALIMA BOUFELFEL and Roberto Cowan are known in the fashion world as the owners of the influential vintage clothing boutique Desert Vintage, they’re historians at heart. Tucson natives, they met as college students while working at an outpost of the used clothing chain Buffalo Exchange across the street from the University of Arizona. Boufelfel, 36, grew up in a family of artists and academics and developed an affinity for styling while costuming school plays; Cowan, 33, comes from a long line of seamstresses and taught himself to sew around age 13. Both knew early on that they wanted to work with historical fashion so, in 2012, after the owner of a Tucson vintage boutique that Boufelfel frequented put the business up for sale, they took it over, keeping the name and stocking it with pieces not only obscure (Jean Varon and Michael Vollbracht evening gowns; an ’80s jumpsuit from a label called Workers for Freedom) but also rare (Fortuny Delphos dresses, a Victorian-era matador jacket). Eleven years later, their collection of some 5,000 items — spanning Edwardian London to Y2K Tokyo — has drawn a global following of designers and stylists, who turn to Desert Vintage both to inform their work and to fill their personal wardrobes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Considine
title: ‘Vera’ Review: No Faking
description: In this hybrid film by Tizza Covi and Rainer Frimmel, the actress Vera Gemma portrays a complex and vulnerable version of herself.
content: It is likely you’ve never heard of Vera Gemma, a minor 50-something Italian actress of the kind who winds up on the extruding end of the movieland meat grinder with all the plastic surgery and little recognition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chang Che
title: A Woman Was Attacked by a Snake That Fell From the Sky. Then a Hawk Dived In.
description: An encounter with two creatures on her six-acre property in Texas left Peggy Jones with bruises and gashes.
content: One should never get in the way of a hawk and its prey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Luke Vander Ploeg, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Jessica Cheung, Mike Benoist, Paige Cowett, John Ketchum, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano, Diane Wong, Elisheba Ittoop and Alyssa Moxley
title: Elon Musk’s Quest to Own the Stars
description: Charting the rise and revolutionary promise of Starlink, the billionaire’s satellite internet company.
content: Satellites owned by Elon Musk’s Starlink orbit the earth and beam an internet connection to almost anywhere. In 2019, the company sent its first 60 or so satellites into orbit — today, it has some 4,500 circling the planet, with around 1.5 million customers across about 50 countries and territories.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Woman Is Sentenced for Stealing Dead Baby’s Identity and $1.5 Million
description: The Ohio woman, Ava Misseldine, used the identity of a baby who died in 1979 to obtain fake IDs. She was sentenced to six years in prison.
content: An Ohio woman and former bakery owner was sentenced to six years in prison and was ordered to pay $1.5 million in restitution for stealing the identity of a dead baby and fraudulently obtaining a pandemic relief loan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Trump Seeks to Review Classified Evidence at His Own Secure Facility
description: Lawyers for the former president proposed using “a previously approved facility at or near his residence” — presumably Mar-a-Lago — instead of a secure location run by the federal courts.
content: Lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump on Wednesday asked the judge overseeing his prosecution on charges of risking national security secrets if he could discuss the classified discovery evidence in the case in the “secure facility” that he once used for classified material when he was in office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Despite Tensions, Salzburg Remains a Crammed Summer Stage
description: No other festival matches the sheer profusion of classical music, opera and theater offerings at the Salzburg Festival.
content: Early in 1779, Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart sulked back to Salzburg, Austria, having failed to land a permanent job abroad. In a letter to a family friend, he sneered at the city he was returning to.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson
title: Another Chinese Developer Teeters, Raising Worries About the Economy
description: Country Garden, China’s last real estate giant to avoid default, has spooked investors after missing key debt payments, rekindling memories of China Evergrande.
content: Remember China Evergrande, that Chinese real estate behemoth whose mountain of debt sent global markets spiraling in 2021? Its collapse signaled the start of a crisis for China’s housing market, where sales of apartments ground to a halt and developers big and small found themselves unable to pay their bills.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Today’s Top News: Biden Declares a New National Monument, and More
description: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: For Disney, Streaming Losses and TV’s Decline Are a One-Two Punch
description: The company experienced a sharp decline in its traditional TV business for the second straight quarter and will raise subscription prices for its streaming services.
content: Robert A. Iger’s urgent need to overhaul Disney — to turn its streaming division into a profitable enterprise and pull back on its troubled traditional television business — came into sharp relief on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Wednesday Briefing
description: A troubled Black Sea.
content: Bordered by Ukraine, Russia and three NATO countries, but sometimes overlooked in the war, the Black Sea has become an increasingly dangerous cauldron of military and geopolitical tensions since Moscow’s decision last month to end a deal ensuring the safe passage of Ukrainian grain.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Bipartisan Plan to Limit Big Tech
description: Responses to an essay by Senators Graham and Warren. Also: Ron DeSantis; Trump trial scenarios; thanks to Mr. Trump; mushroom clouds; macho C.E.O.s.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson, Rachel Richardson and Daniel McGraw
title: Why Ohio Voters Said No to the Ballot Measure
description: In addition to their views on abortion, many who cast ballots in Ohio’s referendum on Tuesday said they felt the measure’s backers weren’t being honest about its purpose.
content: A little after 2 p.m. on Tuesday, David Chrzanowski, 31, walked into Knox Presbyterian Church in Cincinnati, pushing his baby daughter in a stroller. He was there to vote on Issue 1, a measure meant to raise the vote threshold needed to approve a state constitutional amendment from a simple majority, as most states require, to 60 percent.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Five Signs You Might Be Dehydrated
source.name: The New York Times

title: Our Best Grilled Chicken Recipes
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Mutant Mayhem’ Review
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niela Orr
title: The Future of Rap Is Female
description: As their male counterparts turn depressive and paranoid, it’s the women who are having all the fun.
content: As their male counterparts turn depressive and paranoid, it’s the women who are having all the fun.
source.name: The New York Times
